author: Dan O'Donoghue
title: Death threats made against North East MP who campaigned for the UK to remain in the EU
text:
Death threats made against North East MP who campaigned for the UK to remain in the EU 15:51, 26 Jun 2016 The MP for North West Durham, Pat Glass, was told by police to stay away from the count on referendum night Shares Get daily news by email MP Pat Glass 
Death threats were made against a North East MP who campaigned for the UK to remain part of the European Union, it can be revealed. 
A number of threats were made against North West Durham MP Pat Glass and a malicious email was also sent to a member of her family during the referendum campaign. 
Mrs Glass told how police warned her to avoid the count on referendum night as the individual or individuals who made the threats “would be expecting her there.” 
Mrs Glass, who is Labour’s Shadow Minister for Europe, said that she would usually dismiss the individuals making the threats as nothing more than keyboard warriors but, in the aftermath of the death of Jo Cox, she said that threats had to be taken more seriously. 
She said: “There were a number of death threats made against me and that’s as much as I know. I did not go to the referendum count on the advice of the police as they thought it was a place where people would expect me to be. 
“I thought it was just individuals sitting on their keyboards making threats, but after what happened to Jo you have to take more precautions, especially for your family,” 
She added: “I was the Shadow Minister for Europe so naturally I came in for a bit more focus, but one email was sent to my family - that is just beyond the pale.” 
Mrs Glass called for calm following the vote for Brexit on Friday morning. She said: “This has been a very difficult campaign with a massive polarisation of opinion. 
“I really do think it has brought the best and worst out in people. I have never experienced anything like it in 40 years of campaigning - I would now like to see things return to some normality. 
“In the North East, the majority of MPs campaigned to remain and the majority of the North East voted to leave so there now needs to be a time of reflection I think, I believe in democracy and we have to accept the result and move forward now.” More on the EU Referendum
